rememberedPersonSummary.name: BARRIE DAVIS
story:
Barrie Davis worked for Ray Chapman Motors for approximately 13 years and in this period he has formed many close relationships with people he came into contact with.  Many of his customers became close friends.

During the early stages of the lockdown period Barrie started to suffer with stomach and back pains which progressively got worse. Sadly he was unable to secure an appointment with specialists until July, at which point it was identified he had pancreatic cancer. Unfortunately his body was unable to receive chemotherapy and after a short illness he went into St Leonards Hospice and passed away peacefully during the early hours of Sunday, 18th October 2020.

For those of you who came into contact with Barrie, you’ll know
what a tremendously loyal, hard working and above all else honest man he was.

In conjunction with the wishes of Barrie's wife Helen, we are raising money for two charities - Macmillan Cancer Support and St Leonard's Hospice, York.  (Please see the separate St Leonard's Page).

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Hello All, although this page is registered to me, it's Our page, Me, Rachel, Simon, Suzie, and anyone who knew my old man, Chris Baker.

You probably know why you're here. Sadly on 9th October Chris Baker lost his life to cancer. I can't say it was a battle, because it wasn't. His suspected hernia turned into gallbladder cancer and lead to the end of his life in nothing more than a couple of months. In a way I'm grateful there wasn't a big battle, and his suffering was short, but it doesn't make the massive hole left in our lives' any easier to deal with. 

Chris's suffering was reduced (seems weird calling your dad, by his first name), and the support both he and Suzie received from both the Macmillan Palliative Care nurses and the Sue Ryder Hospice at Home team, was second to none. 

The old man's wishes were for donations to made to both of these charities from anyone that can. So I guess between us, we've got the task of making it happen. I have made two JustGiving pages that I'll hopefully be able to merge, giving YOU chance to decide which one of the charities you support. Please try to keep the pages donations balanced. Donations of any size are welcomed. The old man used to say "look after the pennies and the pounds look after themselves". Lets see if they do!

Macmillan have allocated a code, that will see the donation be given to the Peterborough area, which is pretty cool. 

Thanks for your time, your support and your donation! 

Matt Baker

story:
In the month of November, Catrina and I are going to be raising money for Macmillan, joining their Mighty Miles team. We’ll be going on a series of hikes over the course of November with a target of 100 miles all together. We’ll be documenting all our walks on Facebook and Instagram for you to see, so join us on this journey, every Sunday (at the least).

We’ve chosen to support Macmillan because their mission means a lot to me, they’re a great charity that support so many people and do so many amazing things. In the last 3 years they have supported my family many times. In 2017, my Mum, the amazing Deborah, was diagnosed with ovarian cancer, with her tumour growing from the size of a coconut to looking pregnant with quintuplets within a few weeks. After a few months of chemotherapy, My Mum was back on her feet. Not without the support of Macmillan, they invited Deborah to look good feel better sessions. These sessions showed my Mum how to apply eyebrows when there’s no hair, eyeliner and gave her a makeover, they also held a session on tying a headscarf and gave her the opportunity to learn how to care for and wear wigs. These sessions also give women who are fighting cancer a chance to have a chat and a laugh. Giving our peanut the confidence to embrace her baldness. November 29th will be a year since my Grandma passed. She received her diagnosis 5 weeks before she died. It was all quite sudden. But Macmillan provided home care, with nurses frequently visiting. Meaning my Grandma passed away in her own home, surrounded by her family. Whilst I was struggling with my bereavement, I spoke to their support team, who directed me to their online community. There, I was encouraged to write a letter for my Grandma and visit her grave, leaving the letter for her to read. This was massive in learning to live with the loss of my Grandma.   

SO.. our plan!

1st November – Whernside

8th November – Frenzy week (Sunday

8th – Saturday14th) Going to go on as many walks as we can in one week. Follow
Catrina in the Lake District and Myself in Yorkshire.

15th November – Howgill Fells

22nd November – Buckden Pike

29th November – Margery Hill

There are also going to be other walks amongst
all these when Catrina and I have days off together.

story:
In memory of my Dad we are fundraising for the British Heart Foundation. 

In 2004 my Dad Ted suffered a serious cardiac arrest which led to him being resuscitated by defibrillators. If it wasn’t for the advancements in research and technology by the British Heart Foundation we would have lost my Dad back then,  their work gave him (and us) an extra 16 years to lead a fit and healthy lifestyle.   

On the 15th October 2020, my Dad passed away peacefully without any pain after a short illness. I will be forever grateful to the British Heart Foundation, the doctors and all the nurses for allowing a 14 year old boy to grow up with his Dad. 

Instead of flowers we are requesting donations to the British Heart Foundation so the money can be used to help families and their loved ones. 

Thank you 

Sam & Elaine x

story:
A little over two years ago, I was in Gibraltar on a work trip when I got the terrible news that my Dad had died suddenly of a heart attack. I was devastated and, to this day, have found it difficult to come to terms with his sudden passing. However, I have decided to channel the grief I feel every day into something positive. 

I started running earlier this year to help keep my head and heart healthy. I started from the bottom up with the Couch to 5k app and have clocked up a few miles since! I am going to keep up the running and aim to complete multiple half-marathons and at least one full marathon in 2021 to raise money for the British Heart Foundation, in memory of my Dad. 

Given the status of the pandemic, many run events are being postponed so I can't confirm exactly which events I will be able to participate in yet, however, I hope to do the Royal Parks Half, London Landmarks Half, The Vitality Big Half, Surrey Half, The Great South Run and either Brighton or London Marathon. I will update this page as my run events are confirmed! 

Thank you for reading my story and for your support with beating heartbreak forever.

story:
Thank you for visiting our page. 

2020 has been a difficult year so Holland Haven wanted to support BHF to create a brand new initiative that allows children to get ‘fit and elfy’ this Christmas. 

What is the BHF Elf Kick?

Elf Kick is a series of 12 fitness and wellbeing challenges that the whole school from EYFS-Year 6 will be taking part in. The exercises will take part of 12 consecutive days, beginning on the 1st December. The exercises are all Christmas themed, suitable for social distancing and last no longer than 10 minutes. 

Why Holland Haven are supporting the BHF?

COVID-19 has cut BHF research in half, slowing down now puts even more lives at risk. At Holland Haven we believe in keeping your heart and mind healthy. We enjoy exercising and like to take on a challenge. By completing the 12 challenges in December and with your support we can help BHF continue their amazing work! 

Where does my money go?

The money you pay go directly to The British Heart Foundation. 

Keeping You Posted! 

Look out for regularly posts and updates to see how we are getting on! 

Don’t forget to let others know what Holland Haven are doing and help spread the word! Thanks!

story:
Rugby Against Cancer was set up by a rugby player and has a trustee group made up of past and present rugby players who all have their own personal stories dealing with Cancer. One of our first ever trustees Sid (Graham Street) is no exception, he has already had stage 4 bowel Cancer and been in remission but now he is battling cancer again. This time he again has Bowel Cancer and now with secondary Peritoneal Cancer. Which is really tough to take as he has already been so strong and résiliant to overcome it the first time round. 

Often the word legend gets banded around far to easily but if you take a watch of his video diary below you will see why we all think he fully deserves this title. 

Sid is an inspiration to all and to see him sitting up and smiling like that after a 16/18 hour operation is really heart warming. 

He wants the videos to be shared far and wide to help raise awareness of his diagnosis but also Rugby Against Cancer, so please do share away and if you can send a good luck message across to help boost his mindset then please do. 

We as a community are sending our love and thoughts to Sid and his super strong family.

I have taken part in Race for Life at Oxford for the last six years along with my family as part of Jordan’s Army. Jordan is my granddaughter and my inspiration for doing this walk. By the end of two weeks come rain or shine, I will have walked 2 miles or more each day and I hope to have done the equivalent of a marathon or even more.

Jordan was first diagnosed with Hodgkin's Lymphoma in October 2014, at the age of 17. She had to undergo 6 rounds of chemotherapy, and after this she was given the all clear. Sadly, in March 2016 she relapsed and had to have intense chemotherapy followed by a stem cell transplant. She was given the all clear and has been for the last 3 years. Unfortunately, on 23rd October 2020, she found out that she has once again relapsed and is awaiting news on more tests and treatment. She continues to be a strong fighter and a true inspiration to us all.

Please help me by donating whatever you can, no matter how small, to this amazing charity and help me stamp out cancer forever.  Thank you very much from the bottom of my heart  Ann xx

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

A year ago my mum Ruth Kerr passed away after a long fight against terminal cancer. I wanted to commemorate her and challenge myself by doing something i never thought i would and complete a marathon! I absolutely hate running, so a traditional marathon wouldn't cut it for me, but i think the rower marathon distance is equally as challenging! For those who think its not, i added sober October into the mix, which has been a marathon in itself!

Personally Marie Curie has supported my family over the years and I have seen the excellent service they provide. Marie Curie nurses briefly provided care in the home to my mum, and 7 years ago my younger brother-in-law Stuart Simpson passed away after a short battle with cancer while receiving care at the Marie Curie Hospice in Glasgow.

Raising a small sum of only £20 would pay for one hour of vital nursing care for someone living with a terminal illness in the comfort of their own home. 

Many thanks!

story:
As we all know, on the 23 March 2020 the country went into lockdown to stop the spread of COVID-19. Each day I have been completing a daily press up challenge, one press up for each day we have been in lock down! Given that I am now well over 200, and that there is no end in sight, I though that it was about time that I started doing it to benefit a charity. 

With overseas travel restrictions still in place, the services of the RNLI are needed now more than ever. People are flocking to UK beaches, trying new activities in the water, and getting themselves into dangerous situations without even realising it. Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. 

As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.

Thank you.

Since Michael passed away, we have been overwhelmed and comforted by the incredible support and kindness you have shown our family - it is clear how well loved and respected he was. It really means a lot to us that you’ve chosen to join us in remembering Michael by donating to the RNLI.

With a goal of £300, we hope to pay tribute to the memory of Michael and say thank you to the RNLI for their support/multiple rescues!

story:
Our RNLI lifeboats in Ireland protect hundreds of communities through our 24-hour search and rescue service. At Kilmore Quay
there is an all-weather lifeboat on service since 1847. The volunteer crew rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from to be able to save lives.

Irelands unrivalled coasts and inland waters are valued by local communities and visitors alike. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.

Keeping our Kilmore Quay lifeboat maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. Add to that crew training and kit, and the euros start to add up. During the pandemic we have still been offering a lifesaving service and are continuing to raise vital funds,

We haven’t been able to take part in our traditional fundraising this year and rely on donations from the public to continue saving lives. Your donation will help support the running of Kilmore Quay Lifeboat station and its lifesaving service.
